messages.text:
I have some bad memories of the unboxing overhead of functions being pretty bad, but I did some benchmarking last night on 1.6 and now on 1.5, and it really seems to be nowhere near as bad as I though I remembered...
```f(x) = x^2 + 1
g(x) = -x + 4

v = [f, g]

julia> @btime $f($1)
  0.016 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)

julia> @btime $v[1]($1)
  15.281 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)```
There seem to be 3 possibilities:
- I am remembering wrong
- There was a significant improvement made since I last benchmarked this
- I am failing to capture the "worst case" that I am remembering in the above example.
Anyone know which?

elements.text: I have some bad memories of the unboxing overhead of functions being pretty bad, but I did some benchmarking last night on 1.6 and now on 1.5, and it really seems to be nowhere near as bad as I though I remembered...

g(x) = -x + 4

julia> @btime $f($1)
  0.016 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)

julia> @btime $v[1]($1)
  15.281 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)

There seem to be 3 possibilities:
- I am remembering wrong
- There was a significant improvement made since I last benchmarked this
- I am failing to capture the "worst case" that I am remembering in the above example.
Anyone know which?

messages.text:
Hey everyone! Super excited that to say that I was chosen as a speaker for my work to give a talk on Julia! My group is quite tech savvy and are very interested in Julia. They are primarily focused on healthcare and have experience in R, Python, and SQL.

My talk's title - and overall theme - is "Building Bridges with Julia" and I will be chatting about what is it, how is it used, how easy or challenging it is to pick it up, why it is a valuable language, and where to find resources to learn or pick up those skills.

I have some ideas of what I am going to put together, but does anyone have any suggestions/advice on giving a talk on Julia? I'd love to hear your thoughts and I just had to share it with you all as I am pretty excited! :scream:

~ tcp :deciduous_tree:

elements.text:
Hey everyone! Super excited that to say that I was chosen as a speaker for my work to give a talk on Julia! My group is quite tech savvy and are very interested in Julia. They are primarily focused on healthcare and have experience in R, Python, and SQL.

My talk's title - and overall theme - is "Building Bridges with Julia" and I will be chatting about what is it, how is it used, how easy or challenging it is to pick it up, why it is a valuable language, and where to find resources to learn or pick up those skills.

I have some ideas of what I am going to put together, but does anyone have any suggestions/advice on giving a talk on Julia? I'd love to hear your thoughts and I just had to share it with you all as I am pretty excited!
~ tcp

messages.text: Have there been discussions about what it mean to be a `Real` and/or what defines its interface? I feel like I keep running into rough edges because the concept is relatively ill-defined and prone to competing interpretations. For example if a type implement all arithmetic operations and comparisons (e.g. `Quantity`s from `Unitful` that does not subtype `Real`) shouldn't they be fully compatible? And if they are shouldn't they subtype the abstract `Real` type even so they are no strictly speaking reals (or even numbers)?

elements.text: Have there been discussions about what it mean to be a
Real

Real
) shouldn't they be fully compatible? And if they are shouldn't they subtype the abstract
Real
type even so they are no strictly speaking reals (or even numbers)?

messages.text:
I don't trust syntactic sugar and prefer a functional style, so I recommend
```julia> a = [rand()]
1-element Vector{Float64}:
 0.21394202952859032

julia> getindex(a, firstindex(a))
0.21394202952859032```

elements.text: I don't trust syntactic sugar and prefer a functional style, so I recommend

1-element Vector{Float64}:

julia> getindex(a, firstindex(a))
0.21394202952859032

attachments.title: Julia v1.6.0 has been released
attachments.text: The Julia developers are pleased to announce the release of Julia v1.5.0, the sixth minor release in the 1.x series. Some folks put together a blog post highlighting some of the most exciting new features in 1.6. Check it out! As usual, binaries are available for all of your favorite platforms (Linux, macOS, Windows, and FreeBSD) at <https://julialang.org/downloads>. As a minor release, v1.6.0 contains no breaking changes, only new features, performance improvements, and marginal, undisruptive c...

messages.text: Feeding a string with a sequence of parentheses into a constructor I have for young tableaux that never outputs an invalid tableau

elements.text: Feeding a string with a sequence of parentheses into a constructor I have for young tableaux that never outputs an invalid tableau

messages.text: will return the pairs of matched parentheses, while giving unmatched ones their own row

elements.text: will return the pairs of matched parentheses, while giving unmatched ones their own row

messages.text: which works because 1) strings are iterators, 2) chars are comparable and '(' < ')' in unicode, and 3) Young Tableaux obey the Robinson-Shensted-Knuth correspondance

elements.text: which works because 1) strings are iterators, 2) chars are comparable and '(' < ')' in unicode, and 3) Young Tableaux obey the Robinson-Shensted-Knuth correspondance

messages.text: so that basically, using Shensted insertion to force constructed tableaux to be valid means I have an implementation of the Plactic semigroups, and with pairs of parentheses I get the plactic one of order two, which has the right behaviour because of how parentheses are ordered, and strings count as an iterator of them

messages.text: Random conversation. Next week I will having a discussion on my team where I hope to push for the case of Julia. However, with Modern Fortran gaining momentum, how does one justify and argue for Julia? What advantage does using Julia above Fortran (as Fortran is ditching old school) offer? I understand the REPL ability and all (I think somewhere there is a post of Good O'l Fortran is even having a REPL soon), but I'd like to some the community response here. Thanks.

elements.text: Random conversation. Next week I will having a discussion on my team where I hope to push for the case of Julia. However, with Modern Fortran gaining momentum, how does one justify and argue for Julia? What advantage does using Julia above Fortran (as Fortran is ditching old school) offer? I understand the REPL ability and all (I think somewhere there is a post of Good O'l Fortran is even having a REPL soon), but I'd like to some the community response here. Thanks.

messages.text: Why is RoundFromZero only defined for BigFloats?

Hi, the documentation about integer div contains a very confusing phase `Computes x/y, truncated to an integer.` - <https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/base/math/#Base.div>

But x/y is a floating-point operation only and the documentation explicitly says it. So, despite - "The quotient from Euclidean division" - the mentioned phase really looks like referring that it is the same as `trunc(Int, x/y)`. It would be good to clarify it to avoid confusion.

elements.text: Hi, the documentation about integer div contains a very confusing phase `Computes x/y, truncated to an integer.` -

But x/y is a floating-point operation only and the documentation explicitly says it. So, despite - "The quotient from Euclidean division" - the mentioned phase really looks like referring that it is the same as `trunc(Int, x/y)`. It would be good to clarify it to avoid confusion.

messages.text: Why does `Base` have so many functions with the method `foo(f::Function, iterable)` (e.g. `any`, `maximum`) instead of just taking a `Generator`? Is it just to better support the `do` syntax?

Base
